Operation 'SetUpReverseDns' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, vague_description, missing_input_details, missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Original summary and description are too generic. Added specificity about dedicated IP requirement, input parameters (IP and domain), the A Record workflow, return value, and the business purpose (sender verification). This helps AI agents understand the multi-step nature of the operation and when to use it.

data.current_description: **This endpoint allows you to set up reverse DNS.**
data.summary_suggestion: Configure reverse DNS for a dedicated IP address
data.description_suggestion: Creates a new reverse DNS configuration for a dedicated IP address. Requires the IP address and sending domain as inputs. Twilio SendGrid will provide an A Record that must be added to your domain's DNS records. Once the A Record is verified, the reverse DNS record is automatically generated. Returns the created reverse DNS record with verification status. This operation enables mailbox providers to verify your email sender identity through reverse DNS lookup.
data.reasoning: Original summary and description are too generic. Added specificity about dedicated IP requirement, input parameters (IP and domain), the A Record workflow, return value, and the business purpose (sender verification). This helps AI agents understand the multi-step nature of the operation and when to use it.

message: Operation 'GetReverseDns' has semantic quality issues: vague_description, missing_output_details, missing_context. Summary is adequate, but description lacks specificity about what data is returned. Added details about the response structure (IP, domain, A Record, verification status) and clarified the relationship to the list operation. This helps AI agents understand what information they'll receive and how to use it.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to retrieve a reverse DNS record.**

You can retrieve the IDs associated with all your reverse DNS records using the "Retrieve all reverse DNS records" endpoint.
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a specific reverse DNS record by its ID. Returns the complete reverse DNS configuration including the IP address, domain, A Record details, and verification status. Use the ListReverseDns operation to discover available reverse DNS record IDs if needed.
data.reasoning: Summary is adequate, but description lacks specificity about what data is returned. Added details about the response structure (IP, domain, A Record, verification status) and clarified the relationship to the list operation. This helps AI agents understand what information they'll receive and how to use it.

message: Operation 'DeleteReverseDns' has semantic quality issues: vague_description, missing_side_effects. Summary is clear, but description needs to explain the side effects of deletion (disables reverse DNS verification for the IP) and emphasize that the action is irreversible. This helps AI agents understand the consequences of using this operation and make informed decisions about when to invoke it.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to delete a reverse DNS record.**

A call to this endpoint will respond with a 204 status code if the deletion was successful.

You can retrieve the IDs associated with all your reverse DNS records using the "Retrieve all reverse DNS records" endpoint.
data.description_suggestion: Deletes a reverse DNS record by its ID. This operation removes the reverse DNS configuration from your account and disables reverse DNS verification for the associated IP address. Returns a 204 status code on successful deletion. This action cannot be undone. Use the ListReverseDns operation to discover available reverse DNS record IDs if needed.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear, but description needs to explain the side effects of deletion (disables reverse DNS verification for the IP) and emphasize that the action is irreversible. This helps AI agents understand the consequences of using this operation and make informed decisions about when to invoke it.

message: Operation 'ValidateReverseDns' has semantic quality issues: vague_description, missing_output_details, missing_context. Original description is confusing and scattered. Reorganized to clearly explain the operation's purpose (validating DNS configuration), what it checks, and how to interpret results. Added context about when to use this operation (after adding A Record) and clarified the meaning of validation results. This helps AI agents understand the validation workflow and how to handle different response states.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to validate a reverse DNS record.**

Always check the `valid` property of the response's `validation_results.a_record` object. This field will indicate whether it was possible to validate the reverse DNS record. If the `validation_results.a_record.valid` is `false`, this indicates only that Twilio SendGrid could not determine the validity your reverse DNS record  it may still be valid.

If validity couldn't be determined, you can check the value of `validation_results.a_record.reason` to find out why.

You can retrieve the IDs associated with all your reverse DNS records using the "Retrieve all reverse DNS records" endpoint.
data.description_suggestion: Validates the DNS configuration for a reverse DNS record by its ID. Checks whether the A Record has been properly added to your domain's DNS records and whether the reverse DNS setup is complete. Returns validation results including the A Record validity status and reason codes if validation fails. Note: A `valid` value of `false` indicates Twilio SendGrid could not verify the record, not necessarily that it is invalid. Check the `validation_results.a_record.reason` field for diagnostic information. Use this operation after adding the A Record to your domain to confirm successful setup.
data.reasoning: Original description is confusing and scattered. Reorganized to clearly explain the operation's purpose (validating DNS configuration), what it checks, and how to interpret results. Added context about when to use this operation (after adding A Record) and clarified the meaning of validation results. This helps AI agents understand the validation workflow and how to handle different response states.
